summary: This is a Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York Daily Activity Report and Lieutenant's Log for August 9, 2019. It details routine institutional operations, inmate movements, counts, and staffing issues. The document is significant as it provides a snapshot of the facility's operations on a date shortly before Jeffrey Epstein's death, though he is not mentioned by name in this specific log.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: The officer who compiled and submitted the Morning Watch shift report and assumed duties at the beginning of the shift.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: The officer who assumed duties for the Day Watch shift at 8:00 AM and was later relieved by the Evening Watch Lieutenant.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: The officer who assumed duties for the Evening Watch shift at 4:00 PM and was relieved at midnight.

events.title: Daily Operations at MCC New York
events.description: Routine daily activities including inmate counts, transfers, admissions, releases, and monitoring of inmates on suicide watch or in special housing.

events.title: Inmate Transfers and Releases
events.description: Multiple inmates were processed, including treaty transfer returns, new admissions, and releases from the facility.

events.title: Staffing Shortages Impact Assignments
events.description: Several correctional officer assignments (Sanitation, Phone Monitor, Sally Officer, Rec Officer, SHU) were vacated due to a shortage of staff.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The document is a detailed daily log of the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York for August 9, 2019.
It records multiple inmates on suicide watch with inmate companions, and one inmate placed in a dry cell under staff watch.
The report notes persistent operational issues, including an inoperative Control Center Fire Panel and staffing shortages leading to vacated posts.
Inmate movements include admissions, releases, treaty transfers, and placements in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
The log shows routine security procedures like body alarm tests, NYPD phone checks, roof checks, and inmate counts throughout the day.
